cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: If using the spring brakes while hauling a heavy load, a complete stop will:
questions.answerC: Take a short amount of time.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes will activate in a vehicle with air brakes if the pressure in the air system becomes too low. A heavily loaded vehicle will take a long time to stop when using only the spring brakes because the spring brakes do not work on all axles.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared by both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.answerD: Brakes on only one side of the vehicle will work.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual air brake system consists of two separate air brake systems, connected by a single set of brake controls. Each system has its own air tanks.

questions.question: The air compressor is connected to the:
questions.explanation: The air compressor of an air brake system is connected to the engine through gears or a v-belt. The compressor may be air-cooled or cooled by the engine cooling system.

questions.question: A CMV should:
questions.answerA: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless the vehicle will be traveling through remote areas.
questions.answerD: Have a fire extinguisher and other emergency equipment.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system.

questions.question: Leaking shock absorbers:
questions.answerC: Will prevent the turn signals from working.
questions.answerD: Pose no threat if the vehicle is only driven on highways.
questions.explanation: The suspension system keeps a vehicle's axles in place. Damaged suspension parts, such as leaking shock absorbers, may be potentially dangerous defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: When driving through a curve during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer from your lane if needed to complete the curve.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed after entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Refrain from looking for other vehicles while turning.
questions.answerD: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving skills test, you must reduce your speed sufficiently before entering the curve so that you do not need to further brake or shift in the curve. Keep the vehicle in its lane and continue to check for traffic in all directions.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.answerD: Brake with less force than you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination that is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if the vehicle was not equipped with ABS.

questions.question: If driving a new vehicle, you should familiarize yourself with the controls:
questions.answerC: If you feel like you need to.
questions.explanation: When operating a new vehicle, you should familiarize yourself with its features and equipment before getting behind the wheel.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: A safety belt:
questions.answerA: Helps secure a driver in a crash.
questions.answerB: Allows a driver to be thrown within their vehicle in a crash.
questions.answerC: Makes it difficult for a driver to operate a vehicle.
questions.explanation: In the event of a crash, a safety belt keeps the driver of a commercial motor vehicle securely positioned behind the steering wheel. This both protects the driver from injury and makes it easier for them to maintain control of the vehicle.

questions.question: With the exception of the straight line backing exercise, a driver may exit their vehicle and check its position during testing exercises up to:
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic vehicle control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: If you need to travel down a hill, you should switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: As you go downhill and pick up speed.
questions.answerD: Near the bottom of the hill.
questions.explanation: Always downshift before beginning to drive downhill. Forcing an automatic transmission into a lower gear at a high speed could damage the transmission and also lead to a loss of ability to engine brake. Drive at a speed that will allow you to control your vehicle without overusing your brakes. When determining a safe speed to drive, you should take into account the steepness of the grade, the length of the grade, the weight of your vehicle, road conditions, and weather conditions.

questions.question: One way to prevent fatigue on long trips is to:
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should take a break after every 100 miles or two hours of driving. Driving through the night, or during any other time when you would normally be asleep, raises the danger of fatigue.

questions.question: To help your vehicle be seen by others:
questions.answerB: Your headlights should be turned off during the day.
questions.answerC: Your headlights should be covered with grease.
questions.answerD: Your headlights should be used, but only in the rain.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's headlights should be clean during trips. This will ensure that the lights can provide as much light as possible, helping the vehicle to be seen.

questions.question: Watching the road ahead of you:
questions.answerA: Allows you time to make a plan to avoid an upcoming hazard.
questions.answerB: Is not encouraged as it distracts you from driving.
questions.answerC: Is only important when traveling in congested traffic.
questions.explanation: Always watch for hazards on the road ahead. Doing this will allow you time to react to hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.explanation: Steering wheel play of more than 10 degrees (about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch steering wheel) can make it difficult to steer.

questions.question: When driving, you should stop and take a break ____ to avoid becoming too tired.
questions.explanation: To reduce the chances of becoming fatigued on a long trip, a driver should stop for a break at least once every two hours or 100 miles driven.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using flashing lights so other road users move out of your path.
questions.answerC: Drive at a safe speed and arrive when you arrive.
questions.explanation: To avoid engaging in dangerous and aggressive driving behavior, you should relax and accept any delays that arise throughout a trip. To help avoid the stress of arriving late to a destination, plan for likely delays when planning your drive.

questions.question: On a wet road, you should reduce your speed:
questions.explanation: You should reduce your speed by about one-third when driving on a wet road. It can be difficult to stop or turn when operating on a slippery surface, so you must adjust your speed to drive safely under such conditions.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When an S-cam turns inside a brake drum, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Presses the brake shoes against the brake linings.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake linings against the wheel axles.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good rule when using turn signals?
questions.answerA: Signal early. Signal well before a turn or lane change.
questions.answerB: Signal continuously. Do not cancel a signal until the turn is completed.
questions.answerC: Don’t over-signal. If no one is near you, there is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: When using your turn signals, you should signal well before the turn or lane change, signal continuously throughout the turn or lane change, and cancel the signal after you have completed your move.

questions.question: While driving, your mirrors:
questions.answerB: Should only be used when changing lanes.
questions.explanation: While driving, regular mirror checks are essential to remaining aware of the traffic around you. Mirrors are also essential to helping you spot possible problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: In the event of an engine fire, you should not:
questions.answerA: Turn the engine off as soon as possible.
questions.answerD: Spray from the underside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: In the event of an engine fire, you should turn off the engine as soon as possible. Do not open the hood if you can avoid it. Shoot foam through the louvers or from the vehicle’s underside.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Develop your own route to show off your driving skills.
questions.answerB: Listen to directions from the examiner.
questions.answerC: Bring a passenger to ride with you.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must listen to and follow the directions given by the examiner. They will never ask you to drive in an unsafe manner.

questions.question: Foundation brakes are used:
questions.answerC: Only at the driver’s side wheels.
questions.explanation: Foundation brakes are used at each wheel. The most common type is the S-cam drum brake.

questions.question: If being shipped on either a flatbed trailer or a trailer without sides, cargo must be:
questions.answerC: Loose to allow it to shift when the vehicle turns.
questions.answerD: Heavy enough that it won’t shift.
questions.explanation: If being shipped on a flatbed trailer or on a trailer without sides, cargo must be securely tied down to keep it from shifting or falling off while the vehicle moves.

questions.question: Before entering a curve, you should:
questions.explanation: It is important that the driver of a CMV always downshifts before entering a curve.

questions.question: A vehicle must be equipped with all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Warning devices for a parked vehicle.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If your tractor is equipped with ABS but your trailer is not, the ABS:
questions.answerB: Will still improve your steering control.
questions.answerD: Will allow others to see when you brake.
questions.explanation: In a tractor-trailer combination, if the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the ABS will still improve the driver's steering control. The driver should keep an eye on the trailer and let up on the brakes if the trailer begins to swing out.

questions.question: If you doubt that you have enough space to safely drive under a bridge or sign, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are not certain that your vehicle will fit under overhead objects, you should slow down and take a different route, if possible.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. This makes the road look as if it is merely wet.

questions.question: Improperly loaded cargo:
questions.answerC: Reduces stress on the trailer frame.
questions.answerD: Is unsafe, but is unlikely to damage a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Proper loading of cargo is essential for safety. Cargo that is not properly secured could fall off and cause death or injury. Excessive or inappropriate loading could damage a vehicle, and make it hard for a driver to steer safely.

questions.question: When operating a truck requiring a CDL:
questions.answerA: You are never required to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You must always wear a seat belt.
questions.answerD: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if you are driving a tank vehicle.
questions.explanation: A driver's seat should always be equipped with a seat belt. You must wear a seat belt at all times while operating a CMV.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks, you should:
questions.explanation: When crossing railroad tracks during the on-road driving skills test, you must not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in the railroad crossing.

questions.question: What tells you how much pressure is in your vehicle's air tanks?
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: Alcohol usually:
questions.explanation: Alcohol impairs a number of basic functions necessary for safe driving, including muscle coordination, reaction time, depth perception, and night vision. Operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol is both illegal and dangerous.

questions.question: A cargo cover that flaps in transit:
questions.answerB: Allows air to reach the cargo and keep it cool.
questions.explanation: If cargo is covered, the cover should not flap in the wind in transit. The cover could tear loose, uncovering the cargo while potentially blocking your view or the view of others.

questions.question: If you are driving and the ABS light comes on, it means that the ABS:
questions.answerA: Cannot work due to weather conditions.
questions.explanation: ABS malfunction lamps indicate that something in the Anti-Lock Braking System is not working properly.

questions.question: If stopped on the road or shoulder, within 10 minutes, you must:
questions.answerC: Stand behind your vehicle and motion for traffic to pass you.
questions.explanation: If stopped on the side of the road, you must place emergency warning devices, such as reflective warning triangles, within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have ____ malfunction lamps to indicate when the ABS is not working.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with ABS have yellow malfunction lamps to alert drivers when the braking systems are not working. Be sure you know where the malfunction lamp on your vehicle is before beginning a trip.

questions.question: As part of a pre-trip inspection, you should look for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Tires with too much air pressure.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch in grooves on the other tires. Be sure that your tires are not too worn, are not cracked, have proper air pressure, and are all equally sized.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal:
questions.answerA: Is not required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerC: Is optional on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.explanation: A vehicle with air brakes must be equipped with a low air pressure warning signal. If the warning signal goes off while a vehicle is being driven, the driver should bring the vehicle to a complete stop and have the system repaired.

questions.question: What is a way to warn drivers behind you that you will be slowing down?
questions.answerA: Turn on the right turn signal followed by the left turn signal.
questions.answerB: Tap your brake pedal a few times to illuminate the brake lights.
questions.answerC: Swerve from side to side to get other drivers’ attention.
questions.answerD: Turn all lights on and off several times.
questions.explanation: To alert drivers behind you that you plan to slow down, tap your brake pedal lightly a few times to make the brake lights flash.

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you will receive points if you:
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.answerA: Are not required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on in a vehicle with air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Test the brakes while driving, but continue driving if nothing seems wrong.
questions.answerC: Drive with the hazard lights activated.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are operating a vehicle with air brakes, you should stop and safely park the vehicle as soon as possible. It is essential that you are able to stop safely while you still have some braking power remaining.

questions.question: When parked on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear flashing lights.
questions.answerB: Use one set of turn signals.
questions.explanation: Always turn on your four-way emergency flashers if you must park on the side of the road. This is especially important when traveling at night.

questions.question: If you are braking on dry pavement while traveling at 55 mph, how much distance will brake lag add to your overall stopping distance?
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to the vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: When approaching a vehicle for a pre-trip inspection, a driver should look under the vehicle:
questions.answerA: To see if the vehicle is on an incline.
questions.answerB: To see if there are any fresh fluids on the ground.
questions.answerC: To see if the vehicle is in a parking spot.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle before an inspection, make note of its general condition and ensure that it is not damaged or leaning. Look under the vehicle for fresh leaks of oil, grease, or fuel. Check around the vehicle for hazards to movement, such as people, other vehicles, or low-hanging wires or tree limbs.

questions.question: What should be done before transporting an over-length load?
questions.answerA: Special transit permits should be acquired.
questions.answerB: Fire departments along the route should be alerted.
questions.explanation: Over-length, over-width, and/or overweight loads may require special permits from the Department of Transportation.

questions.question: When driving in winter, which of the following should receive extra attention in a pre-trip inspection?
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection during the winter, you should pay extra attention to the coolant level and amount of antifreeze; the defrosting and heating equipment; the wiper blades and windshield washer; the tires and tire chains; the lights and reflectors; the windows and mirrors; the hand holds, steps, and deck plates; the radiator shuttles and winterfront; and exhaust system.

questions.question: If transporting livestock, drivers should be concerned about:
questions.answerB: The vehicle's weight shifting as the animals move.
questions.explanation: Because live animals can lean during curves, and otherwise move in transit, the weight distribution of a cargo of livestock is unstable. Driving with livestock requires special care.

questions.question: When driving, your mirrors should:
questions.answerA: Not be used, as they are distracting.
questions.answerB: Not be used unless there is traffic.
questions.explanation: It is important for you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. To do this, regularly check your mirrors.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Consists of two separate air brake systems that share a single set of controls.
questions.answerB: Is a single air brake system with two different sets of controls.
questions.answerC: Consists of one air brake system for the left side of the truck and one system for the right side of the truck, each with its own set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. The systems share a single set of brake controls, but each has its own air tanks, hoses, and lines. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles while the other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: After two violations of any state law regarding hand-held mobile phone use:
questions.answerA: You will need to cancel your mobile phone service.
questions.answerC: You will be required to drive 10 mph under the posted speed limit for a period of time.
questions.explanation: If you are twice convicted of violating any state law regarding hand-held mobile phone use, your CDL will be disqualified. Consequences will become more severe with subsequent violations.

questions.question: Regrooved tires:
questions.answerA: Should not be used on any vehicle.
questions.answerB: Should not be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: Should not be used on trucks hauling gravel.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous. Warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing; repeated yawning or rubbing of the eyes; daydreaming or wandering thoughts; and drifting out of your lane.

questions.question: Water on bridges:
questions.answerA: Usually freezes before water on other parts of a roadway.
questions.answerB: Usually freezes after water on other parts of a roadway.
questions.answerD: Is not a concern in cool weather.
questions.explanation: Bridges will generally freeze before other parts of the roadway. Be careful on bridges when temperatures are around the freezing point.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerC: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop a short distance later to recheck the tightness of the tire's lug nuts.

questions.question: When checking your tires as part of the pre-trip inspection, you should look at the:
questions.explanation: When checking your tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, it is important to verify that the tire pressure is neither too low nor too high.

questions.question: What can change the height of a vehicle?
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: When you must travel down a grade, when should you switch into a lower gear?
questions.answerB: After you have already started the grade
questions.answerC: As far down the grade as possible
questions.answerD: At the bottom of the grade
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, you should shift into a lower gear. This will help get your vehicle to a speed that you can control without having to use your brakes too much.

questions.question: If backing a truck:
questions.answerA: You should rely on your mirrors to guide you.
questions.answerB: You should first walk the area to become more familiar with obstacles.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should first walk around your vehicle to look at the path of travel and check for obstacles. Because mirrors have blind spots, you cannot rely exclusively on them. It is recommended to use a helper whenever possible.

questions.question: If your truck or trailer catches fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Park in a congested area near trees.
questions.explanation: If there is a fire in your vehicle, the first thing you need to do is leave the road and stop. Park in an open area away from anything that could catch fire, such as plants or other vehicles. Do not pull into a service station.

questions.question: If feeling tired while driving, it is best to:
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the only safe action to take is to stop and get some sleep. Trying to fight the fatigue and press on is very dangerous and can result in a fatal crash. You should not rely on artificial stimulants; these may help keep you awake a while longer, but they won't make you more alert.

questions.question: States verify that a CDL or CLP driver has only one such license by:
questions.answerA: Making phone calls to surrounding states.
questions.answerB: Using a computerized system that links all states.
questions.explanation: All U.S. states share information about CDL and CLP licenses in a computerized database. If you apply for a license in one state, a state will check this database to verify that you do not already have one such license in another state.

questions.question: When it is difficult for others to see your vehicle, such as at dawn or dusk, you can help other drivers by:
questions.answerD: Waving an arm out the window.
questions.explanation: At times when visibility is low, you should turn your headlights on to the low beam setting. If you are having a difficult time seeing others, they are probably having a difficult time seeing you.

questions.question: Most drivers are the least alert:
questions.explanation: Fatigue and lack of alertness are major hazards when driving at night. Most people are the least alert at night, especially after midnight.

questions.question: Air brakes are:
questions.answerA: An effective tool for stopping large vehicles.
questions.answerD: A tool to improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: As long as the brakes are properly maintained, using air brakes is a safe and effective method of stopping large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: To affect a vehicle, ABS:
questions.answerB: Must be on the rear axle.
questions.answerC: Can be on as few as one axle.
questions.explanation: Anti-lock brakes on only a single axle still provides a driver with more control while braking than they would have without any anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: You should move your vehicle quickly.
questions.answerB: You should move your vehicle slowly.
questions.answerC: The move should be made with a jerking motion.
questions.answerD: You do not need to use a turn signal.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly to maintain control of your vehicle. Doing this will also allow a driver that you did not see time to move out of the way of your vehicle. Use the proper turn signal to communicate with other road users.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driver’s side is encouraged:
questions.answerA: Because it allows the driver a better view.
questions.answerB: Because turning toward the passenger side is illegal.
questions.answerC: Because other drivers can offer assistance.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: To receive a hazardous materials endorsement, an applicant will be required to supply:
questions.answerC: A list of countries visited within the last 10 years.
questions.answerD: Their employment history for the previous five years.
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you will be required to submit your fingerprints and undergo a TSA background check.

questions.question: The air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you must show each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: That the oil pressure gauge is working.
questions.answerB: That the oil pressure warning light turns off, or that the gauge shows increasing or normal oil pressure.
questions.answerC: That the oil temperature gauge, if equipped, rises to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: That the oil pressure gauge comes on when brakes are used.
questions.explanation: When checking the oil pressure gauge as part of a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that it is working. The gauge should show increasing or normal oil pressure, or the oil pressure warning light should turn off. If equipped with one, the oil temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerC: Challenge the driver to a road race.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, the most important thing to do is get out of their way, if possible. Do not provoke the driver by challenging them or making eye contact, and do not let yourself be provoked by rude gestures they might make.

questions.question: When changing lanes, turn signals:
questions.answerB: Should only be used if a vehicle is close to you.
questions.explanation: Always signal your intentions before turning or changing lanes. Do not assume that other drivers will move out of your way simply because you are signaling to turn.

questions.question: When driving in heavy traffic, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your cell phone for texting instead of calling.
questions.answerD: Turn up the ringer on your cell phone.
questions.explanation: Areas with heavy traffic, road construction, large numbers of pedestrians, or severe weather demand extra attention from a driver. The driver should avoid all possible distractions while in such areas, including cell phone use.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is ____ in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: If you have an engine fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Open the hood as soon as possible.
questions.answerB: Turn off the engine as soon as possible.
questions.explanation: To keep an engine fire from spreading, you should turn off the vehicle's engine as soon as possible. Do not open the hood if you don't have to.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping on the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brakes are controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. Pull the knob out to activate the parking brakes and push it in to release them.

questions.question: In hot weather, spots on the pavement where tar is bleeding:
questions.answerB: Offer the same amount of traction as the rest of the roadway.
questions.answerC: Offer more traction than the rest of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Tar in road pavement often rises to the surface of the road, or "bleeds," in very hot weather. Watch for such areas because they can be very slippery.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be applied.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should be applied.
questions.answerC: Brakes should not be applied if the vehicle is left out of gear.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should be used whenever you park. If necessary, chock your wheels.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with power steering, the hoses should be checked:
questions.answerB: To ensure that they are still clear.
questions.answerC: To ensure that they are connected to the battery.
questions.answerD: To ensure that they contain the proper amount of play.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: When traveling on a downgrade, your vehicle will:
questions.answerB: Travel at the same rate as on level roadway.
questions.explanation: Gravity causes a vehicle's speed to increase when traveling on a downgrade. Adjust your speed before reaching a downgrade.

questions.question: When checking the air and electrical lines during a vehicle inspection, all of the following should be true, except:
questions.answerA: The air hoses are making a hissing noise.
questions.answerB: The air hoses and electrical lines are not cut.
questions.answerC: The air lines are not pinched.
questions.answerD: The air lines are not dragging against tractor parts.
questions.explanation: When examining the air and electrical lines as part of your vehicle inspection test, you must listen for leaks. Ensure that the air hoses and electrical lines are not cut, chafed, spliced, or worn. Make sure air and electrical lines are not tangled, pinched, or dragging against tractor parts.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: If there is open space in the truck.
questions.answerC: If the amount of hazardous materials in the truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.answerD: If the hazardous materials create an inhalation hazard.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. They identify the specific class or classes of materials being carried and warn others of relevant hazards.

questions.question: A pre-trip vehicle inspection:
questions.answerA: Is not required if the driver regularly uses the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Is not required for trips under 100 miles.
questions.answerC: Is only to be performed by a mechanic.
questions.explanation: Drivers are required by state and federal law to inspect their vehicles before beginning to drive.

questions.question: On a leaf spring, the leaves:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's suspension, you should look for broken or missing leaves in the leaf springs. Any defect of this kind is dangerous. If one-fourth or more of the leaves are missing from any leaf spring, the vehicle must be put out-of-service.

questions.question: A fatigued driver:
questions.answerB: Should take over-the-counter remedies to wake them up.
questions.answerC: May make critical decisions too slowly.
questions.answerD: Is usually more conscientious than a typical driver.
questions.explanation: If you are fatigued, you will not see or react to hazards as quickly as you would if you were fully energized and awake. You will be impaired in making critical decisions.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driver’s side is encouraged because:
questions.answerA: The driver will have the best possible view.
questions.answerB: Power lines should be on the passenger's side.
questions.answerC: Other drivers can offer assistance on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: When driving in reverse, it is always recommended that a driver backs their vehicle toward its left side. This will allow the driver the best possible view of the rear of their vehicle.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection should include:
questions.answerA: A check of the engine oil level.
questions.answerC: Spraying WD-40 into the air filter.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should include a check of components in the engine compartment, including a check of the engine oil level.

questions.question: Leaking shock absorbers:
questions.answerC: Will prevent the turn signals from working.
questions.answerD: Pose no threat if the vehicle is only driven on highways.
questions.explanation: The suspension system keeps a vehicle's axles in place. Damaged suspension parts, such as leaking shock absorbers, may be potentially dangerous defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: If you identify a distracted driver on the road, you should:
questions.explanation: If you encounter a distracted driver, make sure to give them plenty of room. Be very careful if you pass their vehicle because the driver may be unaware of your presence and drift into your lane.

questions.question: One way to overcome the challenges of blind spots is to:
questions.answerA: Drive faster than surrounding vehicles so no other drivers can pass you.
questions.answerB: Drive in the left lane, allowing you to only worry about vehicles to your right.
questions.answerC: Make frequent mirror checks and assess the positions of surrounding vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should make frequent mirror checks to monitor the traffic around you. This should help you notice if surrounding vehicles begin to move into your blind spots.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, you can tell that your vehicle's ABS is not working if:
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the right side of the trailer flashes three times.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights flash and then turn off.
questions.explanation: When turning on your vehicle's engine, the lights on the dash should come on and then turn off. If the ABS malfunction light stays on, the system is not working properly. In the case of a truck with a trailer, if the yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on once the engine has been started, the system is not working properly.

questions.question: If you must drive very slowly, you should:
questions.explanation: If you must drive slowly, you should warn drivers behind you by turning on your emergency flashers, as long as local law permits their use.

questions.question: The two indicators that determine when you should upshift are:
questions.answerD: Oil pressure and air brake pressure.
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: One way to overcome the challenges of blind spots is to:
questions.answerA: Drive faster than surrounding vehicles so no other drivers can pass you.
questions.answerB: Drive in the left lane, allowing you to only worry about vehicles to your right.
questions.answerC: Make frequent mirror checks and assess the positions of surrounding vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should make frequent mirror checks to monitor the traffic around you. This should help you notice if surrounding vehicles begin to move into your blind spots.

questions.question: How does doubling your speed from 20 mph to 40 mph affect your vehicle's braking distance?
questions.explanation: Increasing your vehicle's speed will increase your vehicle's striking power and braking distance. Doubling your vehicle's speed from 20 to 40 mph will multiply its braking distance by four.

questions.question: When doing an inspection, ensure that the brake pads are:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's brakes, you should make sure the shoes and pads do not have oil, grease, or brake fluid on them.

questions.question: During the skills test, if making a turn that requires a stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop after the stop line to get a better view.
questions.answerD: Keep the front wheels aimed straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must come to a stop before making a turn during the driving skills test, you should come to a smooth stop behind any stop line, crosswalk, or stop sign. Keep your front wheels aimed straight ahead and do not let your vehicle roll. If stopping behind another vehicle, stop where you are still able to see the rear tires of the vehicle ahead of you.

questions.question: What is a Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR)?
questions.answerA: The value stated by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle
questions.answerC: The rating of a combination vehicle per axle
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle.

questions.question: Alcohol begins to affect the body:
questions.answerB: After several drinks have been consumed.
questions.explanation: Alcohol consumption impairs muscle coordination, reaction time, depth perception, vision, judgement, and inhibition. For some people, signs of impairment may begin with the first drink of alcohol. It is safest to not operate any motor vehicle after consuming alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: One way to prevent hydroplaning on wet road surfaces is to:
questions.answerA: Ensure that your tires have good tread depth.
questions.explanation: When driving on a wet road surface, the risk of hydroplaning is increased if your tire pressure is too low or your tire tread is too worn. If you begin to hydroplane, release the accelerator and push in the clutch to slow down.

questions.question: One way to avoid becoming an aggressive driver is to:
questions.answerA: Talk on your cell phone while driving.
questions.answerC: Set realistic expectations regarding travel time.
questions.explanation: To help avoid frustration, which can lead to aggressive driving behavior, you should begin a trip with realistic expectations about your travel time. Plan ahead to allow time for potential traffic delays. Other strategies to help prevent aggressive driving behavior include driving an appropriate speed and keeping a reasonable following distance; avoiding making gestures at other drivers; and keeping your hands on the steering wheel.

questions.question: If you must stop on the side of a one-way or divided highway, how far behind your vehicle should you place warning devices?
questions.explanation: If you must stop on or by a one-way or divided highway, you must place a warning device 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet to the rear of your vehicle.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: When there is extra space on a truck.
questions.answerC: Only when the amount of hazardous materials on a truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.explanation: Warning placards are required to be used any time a vehicle is carrying designated types and amounts of hazardous materials. A placarded vehicle must display placards on all four of its sides.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of bad brake drums or shoes?
questions.answerD: Shoes that are not covered in brake fluid
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should stay on for several minutes.
questions.answerB: Should turn off within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Should stay on until manually turned off.
questions.explanation: After starting the engine, warning lights and buzzers should go out right away. If a light stays on, it usually indicates an issue with the vehicle.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no taller than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement in transit.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with the heaviest items on top of lighter items.
questions.explanation: Cargo must be properly secured to prevent it from moving in transit. Loose cargo can be dangerous to the driver operating the CMV, as well as to other road users.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Is common if a vehicle is warmed up.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve gas mileage.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so the vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver confronts you, you should not:
questions.answerD: Try to get out of their way.
questions.explanation: When confronted with an aggressive driver, your first priority should be to get out of their way. Do not provoke the driver by making eye contact, trying to race, or refusing to move out of your traffic lane. Additionally, ignore any gestures that are intended to provoke you.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Make sure your glasses are clean.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you can see as well as possible, don't wear sunglasses when driving at night. If you wear eyeglasses, make sure they are clean and unscratched. Make sure you are rested and alert before driving at night.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started:
questions.answerA: The brakes should be locked up.
questions.answerB: Warning lights should turn on, then quickly turn off.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, you should see the warning lights and buzzers go out right away. If they remain on, there is something wrong with your vehicle.

questions.question: Header boards:
questions.answerB: Protect drivers from being hit by cargo.
questions.answerC: Protect drivers' heads when they are entering the cab of a truck.
questions.explanation: A header board protects a driver from moving cargo in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: When you leave your vehicle, you should:
questions.answerC: Leave the keys in the ignition.
questions.explanation: The parking brake should be applied when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: An over-length load requires:
questions.answerB: A convoy to halt all traffic.
questions.answerC: A person to walk alongside the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Over-length, over-width, and/or overweight loads may require special permits to be transported. In some cases, it may be necessary for the load to be accompanied by a pilot vehicle with warning signs and flashing lights or a police escort.

questions.question: When checking tire condition during the vehicle inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the insides of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the outsides of the tires are more worn than the insides of the tires.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the middles of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the tires have even wear.
questions.explanation: When examining your tires during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that treads are evenly worn.

questions.question: How do ice cream trucks become hazardous to other drivers?
questions.answerA: Ice cream trucks must be kept cold.
questions.answerB: Children often run toward an ice cream truck without looking for other traffic.
questions.answerC: Ice cream trucks leave trails of water and ice on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Ice cream trucks can create hazardous conditions for other drivers because they attract children. Children often do not notice or pay attention to other vehicles on the roadway when running to or from ice cream trucks.

questions.question: When turning quickly to avoid an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply your brakes as you steer.
questions.answerB: Give yourself extra clearance by turning more than needed to miss the object.
questions.answerC: Turn just enough to miss the object and avoid turning more.
questions.answerD: Steer and accelerate at the same time.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid an object, turn only as much as is necessary to clear it. Do not apply the brakes while turning.

questions.question: The front of an enclosed trailer should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting an enclosed trailer as a part of the vehicle inspection test, check the front area of the trailer for signs of damage, such as cracks, bulges, or holes.

questions.question: Who is responsible for the safe operation of a vehicle?
questions.explanation: The person driving a vehicle is responsible for its safe operation. Be sure to perform routine vehicle inspections before operating a commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: The leading factor resulting in death and injury in work zones is:
questions.explanation: The leading cause of injury and death in roadway work zones is excessive speed by passing drivers. Lower your speed when driving through a work zone.

questions.question: If being shipped on either a flatbed trailer or a trailer without sides, cargo must be:
questions.answerC: Loose to allow it to shift when the vehicle turns.
questions.answerD: Heavy enough that it won’t shift.
questions.explanation: If being shipped on a flatbed trailer or on a trailer without sides, cargo must be securely tied down to keep it from shifting or falling off while the vehicle moves.

questions.question: Which of the following surfaces provides the least amount of traction?
questions.explanation: Be especially cautious when driving on ice that has begun to melt. Ice that is wet is much more slippery than ice that is dry.

questions.question: If a person operates in both excepted and non-excepted intrastate commerce, which type of license should the driver select?
questions.explanation: To operate in both excepted intrastate commerce and non-excepted intrastate commerce, you must choose a non-excepted intrastate commerce license.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: If you plan to transport hazardous materials, you must pass which endorsement test?
questions.explanation: You must have a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport defined classes of hazardous materials.

questions.question: Driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Safer than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Just as safe as driving during the day.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued and impaired drivers on the road.

questions.question: During the basic vehicle control skills test:
questions.answerA: A pull-up always counts against the applicant.
questions.answerB: A pull-up should be completed at least once.
questions.answerC: Stopping without changing direction is not considered a pull-up.
questions.answerD: Excessive pull-ups are acceptable in the opinions of some test administrators.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, a pull-up will be scored any time an applicant stops and pulls forward to gain a better position. Stopping without changing direction will not. An excessive number of pull-ups will count as errors.

questions.question: Alcohol evaporators are:
questions.answerB: Used to add alcohol to braking systems to prevent items from freezing.
questions.answerC: Only allowed on vehicles carrying hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems include an alcohol evaporator. The evaporator introduces alcohol into the braking system to prevent the formation of ice, which can cause damage.

questions.question: If there is ice on the front of your side mirror:
questions.answerB: You can expect ice to be on the roadway.
questions.answerC: There will not be ice on the roadway.
questions.explanation: If your mirrors or wiper blades become icy while you are driving, you can expect the road surface to be icy as well.

questions.question: When inspecting engine compartment belts during the vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: The belts should be checked for snugness, each with up to three inches of play.
questions.answerB: The water pump belt does not need to be identified.
questions.answerC: The air compressor belt should be removed.
questions.answerD: The applicant must identify which items are not belt-driven, if any.
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you must check the power steering, water pump, alternator, and air compressor belts. In addition to cracks and frays, you should check the belts for snugness, allowing up to three-quarters of an inch of play at the center of each belt. If any of these items are not belt-driven, you must identify them and ensure that their components are operating properly, are not damaged or leaking, and are mounted securely.

questions.question: If being tailgated while driving a large vehicle, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerD: Try to let the other vehicle pass.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, avoid making quick changes in speed and open up your following distance. This will make it easier for the tailgater to pass you. Increasing your speed is not a good idea because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: What should happen if the air pressure in the air brake system tanks falls below 60 psi?
questions.answerA: A warning light should come on.
questions.answerB: Lights should flash on the outside of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: A message should appear on the control panel.
questions.explanation: On vehicles with air brakes, a low air pressure warning signal will come on if the pressure in the air tanks falls below 60 psi. On large buses, the signal may activate at 80 to 85 psi.

questions.question: Most heavy trucks with manual transmissions require ____ to change gears.
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with manual transmissions require double clutching to shift gears. Learning to effectively change gears by double clutching takes practice.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Before starting down a hill, you should:
questions.explanation: Always downshift before beginning to drive downhill. Take the hill at a speed that does not require you to overuse your brakes.

questions.question: Shortly after a tire has been changed, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop to make sure the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop a short while later to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.answerD: Take the vehicle out of gear.
questions.explanation: Always reduce your speed and downshift before entering a curve.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should never be completed the same way two times in a row.
questions.answerB: Should always be completed in the same order.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if it is sunny outside.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if the driver thinks the vehicle is in good operating order.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: If braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add ____ to your vehicle's total stopping distance.
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to a vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of retarder?
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow the vehicle and reduce the need for braking. The four basic types of retarders are exhaust, engine, hydraulic, and electric.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, you can tell that your vehicle's ABS is not working if:
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the right side of the trailer flashes three times.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights flash and then turn off.
questions.explanation: When turning on your vehicle's engine, the lights on the dash should come on and then turn off. If the ABS malfunction light stays on, the system is not working properly. In the case of a truck with a trailer, if the yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on once the engine has been started, the system is not working properly.

questions.question: Parked delivery trucks may be hazardous because:
questions.answerB: People are often in a hurry when exiting such trucks and may not look for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Packages often fall out of the trucks and into the road.
questions.explanation: Passing parked delivery or postal trucks can be dangerous because the driver may be in a hurry and pull into traffic without warning, or may they suddenly step out of the vehicle without checking for other traffic.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes.

questions.question: When stopped on the side of the road, the driver should:
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important to turn on your four-way emergency flashers to warn other road users.

questions.question: The maximum amount of play that is safe on a 20-inch steering wheel is:
questions.explanation: A steering wheel with play of more than 10 degrees may be defective. On a 20-inch wheel, this is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of the wheel.

questions.question: If you’re not sure how to handle a fire, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are unsure of which method is appropriate to use to extinguish a fire, you should wait for firefighters to arrive and let them handle it. This is especially important when dealing with hazardous materials fires.

questions.question: When doing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Always go through the steps in the same order.
questions.answerC: Not worry about small mechanical issues.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: Be sure you are always driving so your vehicle can stop:
questions.answerA: Within 10 feet of your current position.
questions.answerB: Within 1,000 feet of your current position.
questions.answerC: Within your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: Always be sure that you are driving in a manner that will allow your vehicle to come to a complete stop, if necessary, within the area of the road ahead that you are able to see.

questions.question: During a walk-around inspection, ensure there are no cracks on the brake drums that are more than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a potential effect of drinking alcohol then driving?
questions.explanation: Driving errors that may be caused by alcohol-induced impairment include straddling lanes; quick, jerky starts; failure to signal or use lights; running stop signs and red lights; and improper passing. A driver's reaction time will become poor when they are under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: If feeling tired while driving, it is best to:
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the only safe action to take is to stop and get some sleep. Trying to fight the fatigue and press on is very dangerous and can result in a fatal crash. You should not rely on artificial stimulants; these may help keep you awake a while longer, but they won't make you more alert.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: Applicants seeking a hazardous materials endorsement must pass a threat assessment through which agency?
questions.explanation: Applicants seeking a hazardous materials endorsement must undergo a threat assessment conducted by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: One way to overcome the challenges of blind spots is to:
questions.answerA: Drive faster than surrounding vehicles so no other drivers can pass you.
questions.answerB: Drive in the left lane, allowing you to only worry about vehicles to your right.
questions.answerC: Make frequent mirror checks and assess the positions of surrounding vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should make frequent mirror checks to monitor the traffic around you. This should help you notice if surrounding vehicles begin to move into your blind spots.

questions.question: What kind of force do emergency brakes use?
questions.explanation: Air brakes are really three different braking systems: the service brake, the parking brake, and the emergency brake. Emergency and parking brakes are applied with mechanical force.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Consists of two separate air brake systems that share a single set of controls.
questions.answerB: Is a single air brake system with two different sets of controls.
questions.answerC: Consists of one air brake system for the left side of the truck and one system for the right side of the truck, each with its own set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. The systems share a single set of brake controls, but each has its own air tanks, hoses, and lines. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles while the other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: Which of the following may result in an applicant being denied a hazardous materials endorsement?
questions.answerA: They are not a lawful permanent resident of the United States.
questions.answerB: They have had a speeding conviction within the previous three years.
questions.answerC: They did not correctly answer every question on the written hazardous materials endorsement test.
questions.answerD: They did not pass the written hazardous materials endorsement test on the first attempt.
questions.explanation: You will be denied a hazardous materials endorsement, or lose an existing endorsement, if you renounce your U.S. citizenship; are not a lawful permanent U.S. resident; are wanted for, indicted for, or convicted of certain felonies; are judged mentally defective or are committed to a mental institution; or are deemed by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to pose a security threat.

questions.question: When taking the basic control skills test, drivers are:
questions.answerA: Not permitted to stop and exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerB: Encouraged not to exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerC: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in reverse.
questions.answerD: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in neutral and the parking brake is set.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, you must place the vehicle in neutral and set the parking brake before exiting the vehicle to check its position. You may check the position of the vehicle no more than twice, except during the straight line backing exercise, where you may look no more than once.

questions.question: ABS allows you to:
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to help prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. With ABS equipped on your vehicle, you should drive and brake in the same manner that you would without it.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered an encroachment?
questions.answerA: The vehicle crossing over an exercise boundary line.
questions.answerB: A driver executing a single pull-up.
questions.answerC: A driver placing the vehicle in neutral and applying the parking brake.
questions.answerD: The vehicle stalling while the driver shifts gears.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: A ramp's posted speed limit:
questions.answerB: Is suitable for some vehicles, but may be too fast for a large CMV.
questions.answerC: Is just a suggestion and may be exceeded.
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits on exit and entrance ramps often show speeds that are safe to be driven by cars. However, these speed limits may be too fast for large or heavily-loaded vehicles and CMV drivers will likely need to slow down to a speed below the posted limit.

questions.question: The center of gravity in a trailer should be:
questions.answerC: At the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: The weight of cargo in a vehicle should be distributed as low as possible. Having a center of gravity that is too high will increase the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles thereafter.

questions.question: If you are turning left and there are two available left turn lanes, which lane should you choose?
questions.answerD: Trucks should not turn where there are two left turn lanes.
questions.explanation: A large vehicle may need to swing right to make a left turn. If an intersection has two left turn lanes, the driver should choose the righthand land to begin their turn.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerB: The air pressure has become too high.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: What can happen if parking brakes are used in very wet weather with temperatures below freezing?
questions.answerB: The brakes may freeze so the vehicle cannot move.
questions.answerC: The brakes may suddenly release by themselves.
questions.answerD: The brakes may become too smooth to be used.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should not be used in very wet weather when temperatures are below freezing. The brakes could become frozen in place, making it impossible to move the vehicle.

questions.question: When traveling down a hill:
questions.answerD: You will slow to a stop.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle is traveling on a downward slope, the force of gravity will cause its speed to increase.

questions.question: Lights that indicate that anti-lock brakes are not working are:
questions.explanation: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lights to indicate issues in the braking system.

questions.question: You may be able to identify a distracted driver by if they are:
questions.answerC: Preoccupied with using their cell phone.
questions.explanation: You may be able to tell that another driver is distracted if you can see them drifting within a lane or across lane dividers; traveling at inconsistent speeds; being preoccupied with a cell phone, a map, food, or other items; or engaging in conversation with passengers.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter the cab due to:
questions.answerB: The wrong type of fuel being used.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: When you need to brake, how can you warn drivers behind you?
questions.answerA: Tap on the brakes a couple of times.
questions.answerB: Stick your arm out the window.
questions.explanation: To warn drivers behind you that you are about to slow down, it may be a good idea to first lightly tap your brake pedal a few times to make the brake lights flash.

questions.question: The height of a vehicle’s center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Usually has no impact on the handling the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Plays a large role in a driver's ability to safely handle the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should not be a concern when loading the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Should only be a concern if there are lots of hills on the planned route.
questions.explanation: The height of a vehicle's center of gravity is very important to a driver's ability to safely handle the vehicle. Always distribute the weight of cargo as low as possible.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: If driving a school bus, your four-way flashers should:
questions.answerA: Be activated before crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Only be used after crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerD: Only be used near railroad tracks if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: When driving a school bus, you must activate your four-way flashers while approaching and crossing a railroad crossing. Deactivate the flashers once your entire vehicle has cleared the tracks.

questions.question: Improperly loaded cargo:
questions.answerC: Reduces stress on the trailer frame.
questions.answerD: Is unsafe, but is unlikely to damage a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Proper loading of cargo is essential for safety. Cargo that is not properly secured could fall off and cause death or injury. Excessive or inappropriate loading could damage a vehicle, and make it hard for a driver to steer safely.

questions.question: A commercial motor vehicle driver:
questions.answerA: May use any cell phone while driving.
questions.answerB: May only use a hands-free cell phone while driving, if permitted.
questions.answerC: May only use a cell phone while driving on rural roads.
questions.explanation: If you choose to use a mobile phone while operating a CMV, you may only use a hands-free mobile phone that is located close to you. However, even a hands-free mobile phone can be a dangerous distraction while driving. Make sure you are aware of all cell phone laws in the state in which you are driving.

questions.question: If there is ice on the front of your side mirror:
questions.answerB: You can expect ice to be on the roadway.
questions.answerC: There will not be ice on the roadway.
questions.explanation: If your mirrors or wiper blades become icy while you are driving, you can expect the road surface to be icy as well.

questions.question: Hydroplaning occurs when:
questions.answerA: Tires lose traction with the surface of the road.
questions.answerB: Tires have increased traction with the surface of the road.
questions.answerC: Front tires have more traction that rear tires.
questions.answerD: Front tires have less traction than rear tires.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect that occurs on wet roads when tires lose traction with the road surface and begin gliding along on a layer of water.

questions.question: If a roadway is covered by fog, it is best for you to:
questions.explanation: Driving in fog is always dangerous. If possible, you should always avoid driving under foggy conditions.

questions.question: When starting an engine, oil pressure should come up to a normal level:
questions.explanation: Look at your truck's gauges when starting the engine. The oil pressure in an engine should come up to a normal level within seconds of the vehicle's engine being started.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Stopping distance is affected by a vehicle's speed. The faster you are driving, the longer your stopping distance will become.

questions.question: When only the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: There is a decreased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerB: There is an increased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerC: The brakes will not work as effectively as they would without ABS.
questions.answerD: The brakes will become more sensitive.
questions.explanation: If a tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the risk of jackknifing will be reduced and the driver should still be able to maintain steering control. If only the trailer is equipped with ABS, it is less likely that the trailer will swing out to one side.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause of hydraulic brake failure?
questions.explanation: Most cases of hydraulic brake failure come from one of two causes. The brakes may fail due to a loss of hydraulic pressure or due to overuse on long hills, causing the brakes to fade.

questions.question: If a vehicle is power steering-equipped, the hoses should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: Tie-downs are used to:
