questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers, cargo must be secured by tie-downs to keep it from shifting or falling off while the vehicle is in motion. Tie-downs may also be used to prevent cargo shifting in closed vans. Shifting cargo could affect the handling of a vehicle.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load on a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: A tread depth of ____ should be in every major groove of a front tire.
questions.explanation: For safe operation, a commercial motor vehicle needs a tread depth of 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and a tread depth of 2/32 of an inch on other tires.

questions.question: What does the vehicle inspection report do?
questions.answerA: Inform the motor carrier about problems that may need fixing
questions.answerB: Ensure that the vehicle is inspected regularly
questions.answerC: Keep people accountable for inspecting the vehicle
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection report keeps the carrier informed about any problems that need to be fixed.

questions.question: A truck should be parked:
questions.answerA: So that it must be backed up to leave the space.
questions.answerB: So that it can be pulled forward to leave the space.
questions.explanation: Because you can't see everything behind you, backing is always dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible. Choose parking spaces from which you can pull forward when you leave.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report, the driver:
questions.answerA: Should not look at the report and instead try to find any issues themselves.
questions.answerB: Should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: For the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review the last inspection report on your vehicle, if there is one. The carrier should have repaired any problems noted on the report.

questions.question: When asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror of a school bus is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.answerD: See in front of the bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerB: Still allows you additional control when braking.
questions.answerC: Slows the vehicle, but cannot stop it.
questions.explanation: If you have an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) equipped on only the tractor, only the trailer, or only one axle, you will still have more control over the vehicle when braking than you would without ABS. You should brake normally.

questions.question: On a bus, carry-on baggage should be stored:
questions.answerA: In a manner that allows riders to exit through any window or door in an emergency.
questions.answerB: In the aisle near the front of the bus.
questions.explanation: The aisles and stairwells of a bus should always be kept clear. Luggage and freight must be placed in a location that allows passengers to exit through any window or door in the event of an emergency.

questions.question: If a parent asks you to change the location of a bus stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Agree and pick up students at the new bus stop.
questions.answerB: Continue to pick up students at the original bus stop.
questions.answerC: Change the bus stop if the new location fits into your route.
questions.answerD: Use both locations as bus stops.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver does not have the authority to change the location of a school bus stop. Only appropriate school district officials can determine the locations of bus stops.

questions.question: Containerized loads are used:
questions.answerA: When the cargo is too large to fit on a truck.
questions.answerB: When the cargo has been or will be transported by a train.
questions.answerC: When the cargo is a liquid.
questions.explanation: Containerized loads are generally used when freight is carried partway by rail or ship. Sealed materials cannot be inspected, but a driver should ensure that the containers do not exceed safe and legal weight limits.

questions.question: The emergency brake system uses:
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system.
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system.
questions.answerC: Parts of both the parking and service brake systems.
questions.answerD: Only parts unique to the emergency brake system.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside mirrors should allow a bus operator to see how far behind their bus?
questions.explanation: The left and right side flat mirrors on the outside of a school bus should be adjusted so that the driver can see 200 feet (or four bus lengths) behind the bus.

questions.question: The line that passengers must stand behind is called:
questions.explanation: On a bus designed to carry standing passengers, no passengers may stand in front of the rear of the driver's seat. Any such bus must have a line on the floor, or some other marking, that indicates where passengers may not stand. This is called a standee line.

questions.question: How many classes of hazardous materials are there?
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: When the brake pedal is pushed down, air brakes work:
questions.answerD: Only if it is warm outside.
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: ABS allows you to:
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) help prevent brake lockup when driving on slippery surfaces. If a driver brakes too hard on a slippery surface, ABS makes it easier for the driver to maintain control of their vehicle. A vehicle equipped with ABS should be driven and braked in the same way as a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that lug nuts are all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: During a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that all lug nuts are present, free of cracks and distortions, and showing no signs of looseness, such as rust trails or shiny threads. Verify that all bolt holes are free of cracks and distortions.

questions.question: You should ____ if the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving.
questions.answerA: Stop where you are and park
questions.answerB: Exit the roadway as soon as safely possible
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. These brakes must be held by mechanical force.

questions.question: The ____ tells a driver how much pressure is in the air tanks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: Why do large vehicles use air brakes?
questions.answerA: Other brake systems squeak too loudly.
questions.answerB: Air brakes are very effective systems.
questions.answerC: Other braking systems are hard to come by.
questions.explanation: If used and maintained properly, air brakes are a safe and effective way to stop large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: Brakes can get out of adjustment:
questions.answerC: If they are used at all.
questions.answerD: If brakes on one side are used more often than brakes on the other side.
questions.explanation: Brakes are particularly prone to getting out out adjustment if they are hot. Use proper braking techniques to avoid letting your brakes overheat.

questions.question: A wig wag is:
questions.answerB: A tube that carries air to the brakes.
questions.answerC: A type of air brake system.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with air brakes are required to be equipped with a low pressure warning device. A wig wag is a type of low air pressure warning device. This device drops a mechanical arm into the driver's view if the pressure in the tanks drops to a level between 55 and 75 psi.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, a leak in one system ____ the second system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: If you must drive a school bus during periods of high winds, you should:
questions.answerA: Loosen your grip on the steering wheel.
questions.explanation: You should slow down when driving a school bus in high winds. Keep a strong grip on the steering wheel and try to anticipate gusts.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: A passive railroad crossing:
questions.answerB: Does not have any control devices.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that do not display any traffic control devices are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: Small amounts of a hazardous material may be transported on a bus if:
questions.answerB: There is no other way to transport the material.
questions.answerC: The passengers are notified in advance.
questions.answerD: There is no inclement weather in the forecast.
questions.explanation: Small amounts of hazardous materials may be carried on a bus if there is no other way to transport them. However, there are certain categories of materials that may not be carried on a bus in any quantity.

questions.question: When leaving a vehicle unattended, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Only set the parking brake if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle unattended.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test, failing to exit your vehicle properly during any exercise will result in:
questions.answerB: An extra point against your final score.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If an air compressor is belt-driven, the belt should be routinely checked to ensure that it is:
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. Check the tightness of the belt and verify that it is in good condition.

questions.question: Baggage and freight should be stored in a way that:
questions.answerA: Allows riders to exit by any door or window in an emergency.
questions.answerB: Blocks an exit, if at least one other exit is available to passengers.
questions.answerC: Partially covers a door, since the items can be moved aside.
questions.answerD: Allows the cargo to be easily offloaded in an emergency.
questions.explanation: On a bus, all baggage and freight should be stored in a manner that allows the driver to move freely and easily; allows riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency; and protects riders from injury if items fall or shift.

questions.question: When arriving at a destination, it is best to remind exiting passengers to take their carry-on bags with them:
questions.explanation: Before a bus is brought to a complete stop at its destination, it is best for the driver to remind exiting passengers to take their carry-ons with them.

questions.question: After starting a trip while transporting cargo:
questions.answerA: You will not need to inspect the cargo.
questions.answerB: You only need to inspect the cargo if others alert you to a problem.
questions.answerC: The cargo should be inspected within 50 miles of beginning the trip.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles thereafter.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stop, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Talk to students on the bus.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should always approach bus stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: When stopping at a railroad crossing, opening the forward door:
questions.answerA: Can increase your chances of hearing an approaching train.
questions.answerC: Could allow other noises to enter the bus, making it more difficult to hear any approaching trains.
questions.answerD: Will take too long and is discouraged.
questions.explanation: When stopping a bus at a railroad crossing, you should open your forward door if doing so will improve your ability to see or hear an approaching train.

questions.question: When checking tire condition during the vehicle inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the insides of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the outsides of the tires are more worn than the insides of the tires.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the middles of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the tires have even wear.
questions.explanation: When examining your tires during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that treads are evenly worn.

questions.question: Whenever possible, a bus should be refueled:
questions.explanation: You should avoid refueling a bus while passengers are on board, unless it is absolutely unavoidable. You should never refuel a bus with passengers on board while inside an enclosed building.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerA: Usually have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: Usually have high centers of gravity.
questions.answerC: Usually are not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care when being driven because they have high centers of gravity. Drivers should also be careful because the materials being carried can easily shift in transit, causing a change in the vehicle's handling.

questions.question: If you are taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take a different route.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, if your route does not include a railroad crossing, the examiner may ask you to explain and demonstrate the necessary procedures at a simulated location.

questions.question: When should a bus start moving after students have boarded?
questions.answerA: As soon as the students are through the door
questions.answerB: When the students are near their seats but are still standing
questions.answerC: When the students are seated and looking forward
questions.answerD: As soon as the students cross the standee line
questions.explanation: Once students have boarded a school bus, the driver should wait to move the bus until all of the passengers are seated and looking forward.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time in order to place emphasis on different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time to prevent you from forgetting anything.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: Laws about securing loads and regulating CMV weights may vary from state to state. During interstate travel:
questions.answerA: The law of the state in which the trip originated takes precedence.
questions.answerB: The law of the state the vehicle is in takes precedence.
questions.answerC: The driver should request federal regulations to override conflicting state laws.
questions.answerD: The driver can choose which state’s laws to follow.
questions.explanation: Commercial vehicle weight, securement of cargo, covering of loads, and where large vehicles can be driven are all regulated by federal, state, and local laws. These vary from place to place, so you must be aware of the rules that apply where you will be driving. State laws in the state in which you are driving take precedence.

questions.question: When making tight maneuvers, it is important for a driver to:
questions.answerA: Open the door for a better look.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should always be part of your driving routine, you should make a particular point of checking the mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, or making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: If your wheels being to spin when accelerating on a poor traction surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Take your foot off the accelerator.
questions.explanation: If your drive wheels begin to spin while accelerating on a surface with poor traction, you should remove your foot from the accelerator.

questions.question: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table contains:
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking but the driver does not have access to a phone, they should:
questions.answerA: Drive to a phone to alert emergency personnel.
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean-up facility.
questions.explanation: If a cargo of hazardous materials begins to leak, do not move your vehicle any more than safety requires. If you continue to drive, an even larger area will become contaminated. Instead, you should park your vehicle, secure it, stay with the vehicle, and contact the proper emergency personnel. If you do not have access to a phone, you should send someone else to get help.

questions.question: There may be restrictions on the transportation of explosives or hazardous waste in certain areas. These restrictions:
questions.answerC: Should be researched before taking a route.
questions.answerD: Only apply if transporting more than 1,000 pounds of a material.
questions.explanation: Before transporting hazardous materials, you should research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: If transporting explosives:
questions.answerA: You must have a written route plan.
questions.answerB: You should take the shortest possible route.
questions.explanation: If transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you must follow a written route plan. Whenever placarded, avoid heavily populated areas, crowds, tunnels, narrow streets, and alleys. Be sure to research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely pass under an upcoming bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you are not confident that your vehicle will have enough room to safely pass under an overhead object, you should slow down and seek another route, if possible.

questions.question: Because of tanks' high centers of gravity, drivers of tanks should:
questions.answerA: Take curves at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Drive on the shoulder whenever possible.
questions.explanation: Due to their high centers of gravity, tanks are especially prone to rollovers. When driving a tank vehicle, you should take curves well below the posted speed limit.

questions.question: If you're transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you should notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down while you are transporting explosives and you need to use warning signals, use reflective triangles or red electric lights. Never use burning signals, such as flares or fuses, when transporting explosives.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with power steering, the hoses should be checked:
questions.answerB: For the proper amount of brake fluid.
questions.answerC: To ensure that they are connected to the battery.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle that is equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should look for leaks in the hoses.

questions.question: What does a shipping paper describe?
questions.answerB: How the materials will be transported
questions.answerC: Who should accept the materials being transported
questions.explanation: Among other information, shipping papers must include a description of the specific hazardous materials being transported.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report from the previous driver:
questions.answerA: The driver should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely on the report.
questions.answerB: The driver should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerC: The driver should review the report.
questions.answerD: The driver should speak with the previous driver.
questions.explanation: As the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review any inspection report left by the previous driver.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to get across the tracks as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Roll your window down to listen for a train.
questions.answerD: Never try to outdrive an approaching train.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed as you approach a railroad crossing. Remember that you will not necessarily be able to hear a train, and don't assume that signals will warn you of its approach. Never try to outdrive an approaching train at a railroad crossing.

questions.question: To lower the risk of a rollover, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the cargo as far forward as possible.
questions.answerB: Load the cargo as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Load the cargo as low as possible.
questions.answerD: Stack the cargo as high as possible.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of bad brakes?
questions.answerC: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should check for cracked drums; shoes or pads covered in oil, grease, or brake fluid; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: If a shipping paper has both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials should be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.answerC: Written the same way as the non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: When a shipping paper includes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, one acceptable method of identifying the hazardous items is to highlight them in a contrasting color.

questions.question: When starting the engine as part of the pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.explanation: Check your engine during the pre-trip inspection. After starting the engine, you should listen for unusual noises.

questions.question: Cargo tanks should never be completely full because:
questions.answerA: There needs to be room for the liquid to expand.
questions.answerB: Regulations require three feet of clearance between the top of the liquid and the roof of the tank.
questions.answerC: The tank would be too heavy.
questions.explanation: Liquids expand as they get warmer and drivers must allow extra space in a tank to accommodate this expansion. Different liquids expand to different degrees, so drivers must be aware of the outage requirements of the specific load they are carrying.

questions.question: To complete a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest, you must:
questions.answerB: Sign, but only if you cross into another state.
questions.answerC: Sign, but only if the weather was hazardous.
questions.explanation: A Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest must be signed by hand. The name and EPA registration number of the shippers, carriers, and destination must also appear on the manifest.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You may proceed across the tracks without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track, regardless of the presence of a train.

questions.question: When checking your tires as part of the pre-trip inspection, you should look at the:
questions.explanation: When checking your tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, it is important to verify that the tire pressure is neither too low nor too high.

questions.question: How can a person check for a leak in hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times and hold the pedal for five seconds. If the pedal moves, there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and let go. If the brake pedal returns to its normal position, there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and let go. If the brake makes a squeak, there may be a problem.
questions.answerD: Remove the rear wheel and listen for a noise when the brake pedal is depressed.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: Proper coupling technique:
questions.answerA: Is the same on all vehicles.
questions.answerB: Is essential to the safe operation of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Includes ensuring that the fifth wheel plate is not greased.
questions.explanation: Knowing proper coupling and uncoupling technique is fundamental to the safe operation of combination vehicles. Improper coupling can be very dangerous.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to move in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing a truck is always dangerous because the driver may not be able to see everything behind them. CMV operators should avoid backing whenever possible.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, the vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Parked for only short periods of time.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of a road. Such vehicles should be parked only briefly.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard:
questions.answerA: You should always steer to the left.
questions.answerB: You may be able to drive onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: You should steer sharply in one direction.
questions.explanation: In some emergencies, the best strategy for avoiding a hazard may be to drive onto the shoulder. Most shoulders are strong enough to support the weight of a large vehicle.

questions.question: How do ice cream trucks become hazardous to other drivers?
questions.answerA: Ice cream trucks must be kept cold.
questions.answerB: Children often run toward an ice cream truck without looking for other traffic.
questions.answerC: Ice cream trucks leave trails of water and ice on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Ice cream trucks can create hazardous conditions for other drivers because they attract children. Children often do not notice or pay attention to other vehicles on the roadway when running to or from ice cream trucks.

questions.question: A shipping paper:
questions.answerA: Is not needed for most shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Is required for all shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be kept in a digital file.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide proper shipping papers to communicate the risks of the materials.

questions.question: When checking tires, finding which of the following is not a cause for concern?
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.answerD: Tread of at least 2/32 an inch on rear tires
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's tires, you should confirm that air pressure is neither too low nor too high; that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires; that there is at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth in grooves on other tires; and that radial and bias-ply tires are not used together.

questions.question: In an empty combination vehicle, the stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have:
questions.explanation: An empty combination vehicle will come to a complete stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle. With less weight in a trailer, the stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have lower traction than they would if the vehicle carried more weight.

questions.question: Leaking shock absorbers:
questions.answerC: Will prevent the turn signals from working.
questions.answerD: Pose no threat if the vehicle is only driven on highways.
questions.explanation: The suspension system keeps a vehicle's axles in place. Damaged suspension parts, such as leaking shock absorbers, may be potentially dangerous defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve to open.
questions.answerC: The rear trailer to detach from the combination.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line controls the emergency brakes on a combination vehicle. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerA: Can damage parts of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Is necessary to warm up parts of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve a vehicle's gas mileage.
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: The best way to avoid glare at night from oncoming vehicles is to:
questions.answerB: Close your eyes as vehicles approach.
questions.answerC: Look to the right side of road.
questions.explanation: To avoid being blinded by the lights of oncoming vehicles, you can glance to the right side of the road until the vehicle has passed.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your vehicle in front of them.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, don't let yourself be provoked by their actions or angry gestures. Do not risk provoking the other driver by making eye contact. Get out of their way if you can do so safely.

questions.question: Placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Within three inches of other markings.
questions.answerB: So words or numbers are read from left to right.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be placed on a vehicle at least three inches away from any other markings and must positioned so that the words or numbers are level and read from left to right.

questions.question: How much space should be between the upper and lower fifth wheel?
questions.answerB: A maximum of two inches of space
questions.explanation: Before a trip, be sure to inspect all couplings. There should be no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.

questions.question: When doing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Always go through the steps in the same order.
questions.answerC: Not worry about small mechanical issues.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: If you notice hazardous materials leaking while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Park the vehicle as soon as possible.
questions.answerC: Leave the area to find help.
questions.answerD: Drive around looking for a person to repair the leak.
questions.explanation: If a cargo leak develops while you are carrying hazardous materials, do not continue driving any farther than safety requires. The farther you drive, the larger the contaminated area will become. You should park the vehicle, secure the area, and stay with the vehicle while sending someone else to get help.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has started to skid is by:
questions.answerB: Checking the trailer in your mirrors.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to become aware that your trailer has begun to jackknife is to observe it in your mirrors. Checking your trailer in your mirrors will also allow you to spot any skidding at the earliest possible moment.

questions.question: Without engine oil:
questions.answerA: A vehicle will get better gas mileage.
questions.answerB: An engine can be destroyed quickly.
questions.answerC: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) won’t work properly.
questions.explanation: It is critical that an engine have sufficient oil pressure. The engine can be destroyed rapidly if run without oil.

questions.question: The leading factor resulting in death and injury in work zones is:
questions.explanation: The leading cause of injury and death in roadway work zones is excessive speed by passing drivers. Lower your speed when driving through a work zone.

questions.question: To ensure you do not interfere with traffic while driving a heavy vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to pass other vehicles while driving uphill.
questions.answerD: Ride the brakes while driving downhill.
questions.explanation: If the weight of your vehicle prevents you from matching the speed of surrounding traffic, you should stay in the right lane, if possible.

questions.question: When checking windshield wiper blades, they should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check the wiper blades for damage, stiff rubber, and proper securement. Clean the blades if they are dirty.

questions.question: When traveling long distances, you should:
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should take a break after every 100 miles or two hours of driving. Driving through the night, or during any other time when you would normally be asleep, raises the danger of fatigue.

questions.question: If planning to stop on the road to unload cargo, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop suddenly, since you are already on the road.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers by tapping your brakes.
questions.answerC: Wave your arm out the window to get the attention of other drivers.
questions.explanation: You should tap your brakes and flash your brake lights to warn other drivers any time you plan to slow or stop where other drivers may not expect you to do so. Use this technique when stopping on the road to unload cargo or passengers.

questions.question: After a trip:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should be placed out-of-service.
questions.answerB: A vehicle's oil should be changed.
questions.answerC: A vehicle's after-trip inspection should be completed.
questions.answerD: A vehicle's battery should be disconnected.
questions.explanation: After a trip, you may be required to perform an inspection and file a report on each vehicle that you've driven.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, what is the best method for checking your lights?
questions.answerA: Parking near a mirror to look for a reflection
questions.answerB: Activating the lights, then exiting the vehicle to check
questions.answerC: Looking on the instrument panel to see if any warning lights are illuminated
questions.answerD: Driving in traffic and waiting for other drivers to let you know your lights are out
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should activate your lights, then get out of the vehicle to look at them.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect stopping distance include the vehicle's speed, its weight, and the traction provided by the road surface.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, how can you tell if the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working?
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the rear of the trailer will stay on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the trailer will flash three times and then stay on.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights on the trailer will flash and then shut off.
questions.answerD: The blue light near the driver's door will light.
questions.explanation: Trailers equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are equipped on the left rear with a yellow malfunction lamp. If the malfunction lamp stays on after the engine has been started, the ABS is malfunctioning.

questions.question: When it is difficult for others to see your vehicle, such as at dawn or dusk, you can help other drivers by:
questions.answerD: Waving an arm out the window.
questions.explanation: At times when visibility is low, you should turn your headlights on to the low beam setting. If you are having a difficult time seeing others, they are probably having a difficult time seeing you.

questions.question: What is a bobtail tractor?
questions.answerC: A tractor that travels faster than the speed limit
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as "bobtail tractors." Bobtail tractors are difficult to operate and drivers must exercise caution.

questions.question: What does an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) do?
questions.answerA: It allows a vehicle's wheels to lock up.
questions.answerB: It prevents a vehicle's wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: It makes turning a vehicle easier.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. If ABS detects impending lockup, it reduces braking pressure to a safe level.

questions.question: A thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces is called:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: Eating while driving:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to maximize your time.
questions.answerC: Is a distraction to the driver.
questions.explanation: Eating while driving can be a dangerous distraction to the driver both because it diverts their attention away from the task at hand and requires them to remove a hand from the steering wheel.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a problem?
questions.answerC: Exhaust parts rubbing against fuel system parts
questions.answerD: Exhaust system parts that are not leaking
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used if carrying a light load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are never safe to use.

questions.question: When going down a steep downhill, your primary source of braking should be:
questions.explanation: On a steep downgrade, you must use the engine's braking effect as your primary method of speed control. Be sure to decelerate and downshift appropriately before beginning to drive down the hill.

questions.question: What should you do if the brake pedal does not build up pressure?
questions.answerC: Hold the brake pedal down as far as it will go.
questions.explanation: If you lose pressure in a hydraulic brake system, one appropriate response is to shift down into a lower gear. This will help slow the vehicle.

questions.question: When coupling, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple the proper glad hands.
questions.answerB: Only couple one set of glad hands.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand loose.
questions.explanation: When coupling air brake hoses, you should make sure the proper pairs of gland hands are connected. They are sometimes color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerB: Tires are not made to drive in wet weather.
questions.answerC: The water yet hasn't absorbed the dirt and grease.
questions.explanation: Roads are often especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Rainwater forms a slick film when mixed with oil and grease on the road surface that has not yet washed away.

questions.question: To prevent a trailer from rolling over, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up when nearing a corner.
questions.answerC: Take on-ramps faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover when driving a combination vehicle, you should keep the weight of the cargo as low to the ground as possible and drive slowly around turns.

questions.question: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and figure out what's wrong.
questions.explanation: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should stop driving as soon as possible and try to figure out what is wrong. There could be an issue in your vehicle that could lead to engine failure and possibly a fire.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, the heaviest cargo should be placed:
questions.answerA: On top of the lightest parts of the cargo.
questions.answerB: Under the lightest parts of the cargo.
questions.answerC: At the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is important that vehicles are not top-heavy, if at all possible. A top-heavy vehicle is at an increased risk of rollover. Place the heaviest pieces of cargo underneath lighter pieces of cargo.

questions.question: When carrying a wide load, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Obtain special permits and follow special rules.
questions.answerC: Honk at other drivers to get them to move from the lane closest to you.
questions.explanation: Special permits are required for over-length, over-width, and/or overweight loads. They may also be subject to certain driving restrictions.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.answerD: Brake with less force than you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination that is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if the vehicle was not equipped with ABS.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Is common if a vehicle is warmed up.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve gas mileage.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so the vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: If you plan to slow down, you can warn drivers behind you by:
questions.answerB: Tapping the brakes a few times and before braking.
questions.answerC: Turning on one set of turn signals.
questions.explanation: Before slowing down, it is a good idea to flash your brake lights by lightly tapping your brake pedal a few times. This will warn drivers behind you of your plans to slow down.

questions.question: Before coupling, you can secure a second trailer by:
questions.explanation: If you are attaching a second trailer to a combination but you have doubts about the trailer's brakes, you should use wheel chocks to secure the trailer in place while coupling.

questions.question: If you are driving and the ABS light comes on, it means that the ABS:
questions.answerA: Cannot work due to weather conditions.
questions.explanation: ABS malfunction lamps indicate that something in the Anti-Lock Braking System is not working properly.

questions.question: Which of the following does not indicate bad brakes?
questions.answerB: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should check for cracked drums; shoes or pads covered in oil, grease, or brake fluid; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels:
questions.answerA: Follow the same path as the front wheels.
questions.answerB: Follow a different path than the front wheels.
questions.answerC: Should not be a concern to the driver.
questions.explanation: When any vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is called off-tracking. The degree of off-tracking will be greater on long vehicles than on short vehicles.

questions.question: When using mirrors while driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Look in the mirrors for extended periods of time.
questions.answerD: Use only the driver’s side mirror.
questions.explanation: Focusing on your mirrors for too long can be dangerous because you will have traveled a substantial distance without looking at the road ahead.

questions.question: To make driving at night easier, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your interior light turned on.
questions.answerB: Adjust the instrument panel lights as dimly as you can while still being able to read the gauges.
questions.answerC: Not take a nap before driving.
questions.answerD: Use only your low beam headlights.
questions.explanation: If the interior of your cab is too bright when you are driving at night, you may have difficulty seeing things outside. Keep the interior light off and adjust your instrument lights to the lowest possible level that still allows you to easily read the gauges.

questions.question: What is a tire load?
questions.answerA: The minimum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.answerB: The maximum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.answerD: The weight of the air within a fully inflated tire
questions.explanation: Tire load is the maximum weight that a tire can safely carry at a specified pressure. This will be stated on the side of a tire.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerB: Usually happens when vehicles are traveling at speeds above 65 mph.
questions.answerC: Can occur with a minimal amount of water on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be a large amount of water on the road for this to occur. Hydroplaning can begin at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: Suspension system defects may include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Defects to check for when inspecting your vehicle's suspension system include cracked or broken spring hangers; missing or broken leaves in a leaf spring; and leaking shock absorbers. If you spot any of these issues, be sure to have them repaired.

questions.question: If carrying a heavy load that is slowing you down, you should:
questions.answerD: Keep the vehicle in second gear.
questions.explanation: The right lanes of a roadway are generally intended for vehicles traveling more slowly than surrounding traffic. If being slowed down by a heavy load, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: Older trailers are not equipped with spring brakes. This means that if the air supply for a vehicle's air braking system leaks away:
questions.answerB: The trailer will not have brakes.
questions.explanation: Older trailers do not have spring brakes. This means that if the air supply in an older trailer's air tank has leaked away, there will be no working brakes connected to the trailer and its wheels will turn freely.

questions.question: What is a tire load?
questions.answerA: The minimum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.answerB: The maximum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.explanation: Tire load is defined as the maximum safe weight that a tire can carry at a specified pressure.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with one or more trailers, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the trailers are straight. Mirror adjustment should be checked before the start of every trip.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, a driver should:
questions.answerC: Cross the tracks before an approaching train reaches the crossing.
questions.explanation: You should approach every railroad crossing with the expectation that a train is coming. Do not rely on signals or your hearing to reliably tell you if a train is present. Always slow down when approaching a crossing. Never try to race a train.

questions.question: To prevent a vehicle from rolling backward when beginning to move forward from a stopped position, you should:
questions.explanation: To prevent a vehicle with manual transmission from rolling backward when you begin to move forward from a stopped position, you can partly engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.

questions.question: If you use the trailer hand brake while your trailer is skidding, it will:
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a trailer jackknife, you can help your tires regain traction by releasing the brakes. Using a trailer hand brake while experiencing a skid will only cause the skid to continue.

questions.question: In extremely hot conditions, you may have to:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to cool the engine.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed to prevent overheating.
questions.answerD: Follow other vehicles more closely than normal.
questions.explanation: Faster speeds create more heat in the engine and tires, so slow down to avoid dangerous overheating when the weather is very hot.

questions.question: Slow down and be extra careful:
questions.explanation: Slow down and be especially careful when driving in and around work zones, in places where the pavement drops off sharply at the edge of the road, when foreign objects are present on the road, and on freeway on- and off-ramps.

questions.question: The "crack-the-whip" effect is caused by:
questions.explanation: Vehicles with trailers are vulnerable to rollover due to the "crack-the-whip" effect, which is caused by rearward amplification. Rearward amplification varies from vehicle to vehicle, so it is important that drivers are aware of the rearward amplification of their specific vehicles.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, but have the brakes repaired within a week.
questions.answerB: Pull over and inspect the brakes.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should immediately bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes. Inspect and repair the brakes as soon as possible.

questions.question: While driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Develop plans to get out of any dangerous situation that could arise.
questions.answerD: Focus on your own driving and not worry about other drivers.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should consistently check the road ahead for hazards. Develop a plan to deal with any hazards that could arise.

questions.question: Cargo on flatbed trailers should be:
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers or trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down to keep it from shifting or falling in transit.

questions.question: What is a tire load?
questions.answerA: The minimum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.answerB: The maximum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.answerD: The weight of the air within a fully inflated tire
questions.explanation: Tire load is the maximum weight that a tire can safely carry at a specified pressure. This will be stated on the side of a tire.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of tire failure?
questions.explanation: If you experience tire failure, you may hear the loud "bang" sound of a blowout or feel a heavy thumping or vibration in your vehicle. If steering begins to feel heavy, or if the rear of your vehicle begins to fishtail, you should stop to check your tires.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Detaching and reattaching the rear shut-off valves.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves at the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: It is best not to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive under foggy conditions, be sure to decrease your speed.

questions.question: Unless a package is clearly unsafe, what does the driver need to accept a package of hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: Unless a package is clearly unsafe or does not comply with the Hazardous Materials Regulations, you may accept the shipper's certification that it was properly packaged.

questions.question: During an inspection, it is most important to check your tank vehicle for:
questions.explanation: When inspecting any style of tank, the most important thing for a driver to check for is leaks. Transporting any type of gas or liquid in a leaking tank is illegal.

questions.question: Carry-on bags should be placed:
questions.answerA: In front of the back door.
questions.answerB: In front of the front door.
questions.answerC: In a location that allows easy access to all emergency exits.
questions.explanation: Bus passengers should not be allowed to leave baggage in any doorway or aisle. Baggage and freight must be secured in a manner that will prevent damage, allow the driver to move freely and easily, allow riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency, and protect riders from injury if the items fall or shift.

questions.question: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package:
questions.answerB: Has been prepared in compliance with the rules.
questions.answerC: Was packed at a specific location.
questions.answerD: Will be placed on the trailer first.
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they are certifying that the package has been prepared in accordance with its applicable rules.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.explanation: Brace containers so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation. All hazardous materials packages must be secured.

questions.question: A bridge formula:
questions.answerA: Permits less weight per axle for axles that are close together.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern for drivers.
questions.explanation: Maximum axle weights are often set by a bridge formula, which sets a lower maximum weight for axles that are close together.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 materials should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gases), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids), the use of heaters in the same space is generally prohibited.

questions.question: Before driving, access panels should be:
questions.explanation: You should always inspect the outside of your bus before driving. During this inspection, make sure to close all emergency exits and access panels.

questions.question: Loading cargo onto a vehicle:
questions.answerA: Must be done by the driver.
questions.answerB: May be done by a person other than the driver, and they become responsible for the safety of the cargo.
questions.answerC: May be done by a person other than the driver, but the driver is responsible for the safety of the cargo.
questions.answerD: Must be done by a professional loader.
questions.explanation: Even if someone else loads cargo onto a vehicle, the driver is responsible for properly inspecting the cargo, ensuring that it is properly loaded and secured, and ensuring that it does not obscure their view or access to emergency equipment.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerC: Does not need to know the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must be within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading of a tank with hazardous materials must always be watched by a qualified person. This person must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: When stopped at a railroad crossing, one way for a bus driver to hear if a train is approaching is by:
questions.answerC: Waiting for the passengers on the bus to quiet down on their own.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing, buses should stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track and the driver should look both ways for a train. They should open the forward door if it improves their ability to see or hear an oncoming train.

questions.question: What does blocking cargo do?
questions.answerA: Holds the cargo in a large box
questions.answerB: Prevents cargo from sliding in transit
questions.answerC: Prevent others from buying the cargo
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit.

questions.question: Buses must never transport:
questions.explanation: While buses may carry some hazardous materials under certain conditions, they must never be used to transport tear gas or irritating materials.

questions.question: If hazardous materials are being transported, how are other drivers warned?
questions.answerA: By the posting of placards on the truck
questions.answerB: By the flashing lights on the truck
questions.answerD: By the driver waving an arm out the window
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs called placards are placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials to alert other drivers to the presence of the materials.

questions.question: If there is a collision involving a vehicle transporting Class 1 explosives, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Not warn others of the danger.
questions.answerC: Keep the explosives inside the vehicle until after separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.answerD: Remove the explosives from the vehicle before separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.explanation: If you are driving a vehicle that is transporting Class 1 explosives and it is involved in an accident, you should warn others of the danger, keep bystanders away, and not allow smoking or open fires near the vehicle. Before separating the vehicles involved in the collision, remove all explosives and place them at least 200 feet away from the vehicles and any occupied buildings.

questions.question: A manifest for transporting hazardous waste:
questions.answerC: Must be attached to the outside of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting hazardous waste, you must carry with you a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. The manifest must be signed by hand.

questions.question: Which type of product is usually transported by unbaffled tanks?
questions.explanation: Baffles make a tank difficult to clean. For this reason, regulations usually require the use of unbaffled tanks to transport food products, like milk.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: May only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerC: May be driven if the cargo is not radioactive.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that lacks the proper placards for any hazardous materials on board may not be driven, except as necessary to protect life and property in an emergency.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle that contains hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.answerD: No other vehicles should be at the refueling station.
questions.explanation: If you need to refuel a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, you must first turn off the engine. While refueling, someone must be at the nozzle and controlling the fuel flow at all times.

questions.question: A posted speed limit for cars:
questions.answerB: May be too fast for buses.
questions.answerC: May be too slow for buses.
questions.explanation: Particularly on curves, the maximum posted speed limit may be safe to be driven in a car but too fast to be driven in a bus. Be especially careful when the road has been made slippery by rain or snow.

questions.question: During a bus ride:
questions.answerA: Carry-on baggage may be kept in the aisle.
questions.answerB: Passengers may sit in the aisle.
questions.answerC: Aisles must remain free of obstacles.
questions.answerD: Items may be placed in the aisle if passengers could easily step over them.
questions.explanation: Do not allow riders to leave carry-on baggage in any doorway or aisle. There should be nothing in the aisle that might trip other riders. Secure baggage in a way that prevents damage.

questions.question: Tanks have high centers of gravity, which means:
questions.answerA: They get very good gas mileage.
questions.answerB: They are easy to roll over.
questions.explanation: Tank vehicles have high centers of gravity, which makes them vulnerable to rollover.

questions.question: In general, before loading or unloading any flammable liquids, an engine should be:
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: Identification numbers assigned to chemicals can be found:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guidebook.
questions.explanation: The United States Department of Transportation (DOT)’s Emergency Response Guidebook (ERG) lists all hazardous chemicals and their assigned identification numbers.

questions.question: Driving with a cargo of hanging meat in a trailer:
questions.answerA: Is discouraged during the summer months.
questions.answerB: Can be problematic because animals are attracted to the smell of the meat.
questions.answerC: Is challenging because the load has a high center of gravity.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: When loading or unloading a tank that is divided by bulkheads, equal weight distribution is:
questions.explanation: Some tanks are divided into multiple smaller tanks by bulkheads. When loading or unloading such tanks, pay attention to weight distribution. Be careful not to place too much weight on a single end of the tank.

questions.question: Manhole covers:
questions.answerA: May be open when a vehicle is being driven.
questions.answerB: Should be closed when a vehicle is being driven.
questions.answerD: Should be removed when a vehicle is being driven.
questions.explanation: Be sure to inspect your vehicle before driving. Never drive a tank vehicle with open valves or manhole covers.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed, except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: A bus should be refueled:
questions.answerA: In a closed building while passengers are on board.
questions.answerB: In any location while passengers are on board.
questions.answerC: Without passengers on board, unless absolutely necessary.
questions.explanation: A bus should not be refueled while passengers are on board, unless it is absolutely unavoidable. A bus with passengers on board should never be refueled inside an enclosed building.

questions.question: An underloaded front axle:
questions.answerB: Is encouraged as front axles are usually less strong than other axles.
questions.answerC: Is discouraged as it can cause steering problems.
questions.answerD: Is discouraged as it can improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: Underloading a front axle may make it impossible to safely steer your vehicle. Keep weight distribution in mind when loading cargo.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you must park at least ____ from any building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, do not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building; a place where people gather; or an open fire.

questions.question: Outage:
questions.answerA: Is only a concern in warm weather.
questions.answerB: Is the same for each liquid.
questions.answerC: Should be a factor when determining how much liquid to load into a tank vehicle.
questions.explanation: Because liquids expand when their temperatures increase, some space must be left in a tank to accommodate the expansion. This space is referred to as "outage." The amount of required outage is different for different liquids.

questions.question: During an inspection, it is most important to check your tank vehicle for:
questions.explanation: When inspecting any style of tank, the most important thing for a driver to check for is leaks. Transporting any type of gas or liquid in a leaking tank is illegal.

questions.question: Containerized loads are used:
questions.answerA: When the cargo is too large to fit on a truck.
questions.answerB: When the cargo has been or will be transported by a train.
questions.answerC: When the cargo is a liquid.
questions.explanation: Containerized loads are generally used when freight is carried partway by rail or ship. Sealed materials cannot be inspected, but a driver should ensure that the containers do not exceed safe and legal weight limits.

questions.question: As the driver of a truck carrying a load, you are responsible for all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Knowing the phone numbers of all fire departments along your intended route of travel.
questions.explanation: It is the driver's responsibility to inspect their cargo; recognize overloading or poorly balanced weight; know that the cargo is properly secured and does not obscure the driver's view; and know that the cargo does not restrict access to emergency equipment. The driver is responsible for their cargo even if they were not the one who initially loaded and secured the cargo.

questions.question: If the letter “G” appears in Column 1 of a hazardous materials shipping paper, the shipping paper must also include:
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: A "G" in Column 1 of a hazardous materials shipping paper indicates that the description in Column 2 is the generic name for a material. A generic shipping name must be accompanied by a technical name.

questions.question: Surges are strongest in:
questions.explanation: Baffled and unbaffled bulkheads in tanks serve to inhibit the forward and backward surge of liquid cargo.

questions.question: A posted speed limit for cars:
questions.answerB: May be too fast for buses.
questions.answerC: May be too slow for buses.
questions.explanation: Particularly on curves, the maximum posted speed limit may be safe to be driven in a car but too fast to be driven in a bus. Be especially careful when the road has been made slippery by rain or snow.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of tie-downs required to secure a 10-foot piece of cargo?
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down. There should be at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Regardless of the size of the cargo, at least two tie-downs must be used.

questions.question: How is water and compressor oil removed from the bottom of an air storage tank?
questions.answerA: The water and oil are siphoned out of the tank.
questions.answerB: A drain valve is opened to remove the water and oil from the tank.
questions.answerC: The water and oil are removed automatically as the brakes are used.
questions.answerD: A sponge is used to soak up the water and oil.
questions.explanation: Water and compressor oil are removed from air storage tanks through a drain valve. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated tanks must be drained every day to remove this build-up.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should be done in the same way every time.
questions.answerB: Should be done differently every time.
questions.answerC: Does not always need to include all items of concern.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip vehicle inspection should be done in the same way every time. Consistency will help a driver learn all of the proper steps and decrease the possibility of the driver forgetting to inspect something.

questions.question: After picking up passengers at a stop, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Allow the passengers time to sit or brace themselves before beginning to drive.
questions.answerB: Honk their horn and re-enter traffic.
questions.answerC: Begin driving as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: You should start and stop as smoothly as possible to help prevent passenger injury. After passengers have boarded your bus at a stop, you should allow them time to be seated or to brace themselves before you begin driving.

questions.question: A disruptive passenger should be:
questions.answerA: Removed from the bus as quickly as possible, regardless of location.
questions.answerB: Discharged at the next bus stop.
questions.answerC: Kept on the bus and taken to the police department.
questions.explanation: Even if a passenger is disruptive, a bus driver is still responsible for their safety. The passenger should be discharged in a safe place, either at the next scheduled stop or in another well-lit area where other people are present.

questions.question: If you identify a distracted driver on the road, you should:
questions.explanation: If you encounter a driver who seems distracted on the road, you should give them plenty of room and maintain a safe following distance.

questions.question: When checking your windshield wiper blades, the blades should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check the wiper blades for damage, stiff rubber, and proper securement.

questions.question: For a basic vehicle control skills test, you are expected to be able to:
questions.answerB: Weave between a line of cones.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: You should specifically look out for black ice:
questions.answerB: When the temperature is below freezing and the road looks wet.
questions.answerC: When the temperature is above freezing and there is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. Be alert to black ice any time the temperature is below freezing and the road surface looks wet.

questions.question: To make a stop in a vehicle using air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Lift the brake pedal toward them.
